title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: Setup connection Opal:
code: library(opalr) o <- opal.login("administrator", "password", "https://opal-demo.obiba.org")

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: Opal can handle clusters R servers. R packages handled cluster level (R servers cluster expected identical). See Opal R server documentation. List installed DataSHIELD R packages: Install DataSHIELD R package configured CRAN repositories (likely DataSHIELD repo): R packages source code one GitHub can installed directly: developing new DataSHIELD R package, can built installed follow (root R package source directory): remove DataSHIELD R package: Note removing package update DataSHIELD settings associated profiles. See following sections administrate profiles settings.
code: dsadmin.package_descriptions(o, profile = "default") dsadmin.install_package(o, pkg = "dsBase", profile = "default") dsadmin.install_github_package(o, pkg = "dsSurvival", username = "neelsoumya", ref = "v1.0.0", profile = "default") dsadmin.install_local_package(o, devtools::build(), profile = "default") dsadmin.remove_package(o, pkg = "dsSurvival", profile = "default")

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: DataSHIELD profile based R servers cluster. simple setup, one cluster one R server cluster called default, profile named . possible define several profiles based cluster. benefit : different configurations (allowed aggregate assigned functions, R option values), restrict access users/groups. list DataSHIELD profiles: create new DataSHIELD profile, initialize DataSHIELD settings declared installed packages enable , use following. DataSHIELD R package installed used restricted group users, proceed follow:
code: dsadmin.profiles(o) # ensure the profile does not exist if (dsadmin.profile_exists(o, "demo"))   dsadmin.profile_delete(o, "demo") # create a profile, disabled dsadmin.profile_create(o, "demo", cluster = "default") # make only dsBase and resourcer packages visible dsadmin.profile_init(o, "demo", packages = c("dsBase", "resourcer")) # ready to be used dsadmin.profile_enable(o, "demo") dsadmin.profile_perm_add(o, "demo", subject = "testers", type = "group") # verify permissions dsadmin.profile_perm(o, "demo")

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: DataSHIELD settings defined per profile (DataSHIELD Profiles section). settings can minimally initialized reading declared settings installed DataSHIELD R packages. can also amended afterwards.

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: DataSHIELD methods define allowed function calls mapping server side function call. list aggregation functions: Fully custom settings can defined (useful developers). simple test custom hello() function :
code: dsadmin.get_methods(o, type = "aggregate", profile = "demo") dsadmin.set_method(o, "hello", func = function(x) { paste0("Hello ", x, "!") }, type = "aggregate", profile = "demo") # verfiy custom method  dsadmin.get_method(o, "hello", type = "aggregate", profile = "demo") library(DSOpal) builder <- DSI::newDSLoginBuilder() builder$append(server = "study1",  url = "https://opal-demo.obiba.org",                user = "administrator", password = "password",                profile = "demo") logindata <- builder$build() conns <- DSI::datashield.login(logins = logindata) # call the hello() function on the R server datashield.aggregate(conns, expr = quote(hello('friends'))) datashield.logout(conns)

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: DataSHIELD R options affects behaviour methods. modify R option:
code: dsadmin.set_option(o, "datashield.privacyLevel", "10", profile = "demo") # verify options dsadmin.get_options(o, profile = "demo")

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: advanced setting, mostly backward compatibility issues, possibility chose R parser used Opal validating submitted R code (remember subset R language allowed). See datashield4j library documentation possible values. set legacy R parser:
code: dsadmin.profile_rparser(o, "demo", rParser = "v1")

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: DataSHIELD requires permissions: permissions access data (whether table resource) permission use DataSHIELD service.

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: facilitate permissions maintenance, create users appropriate group(s). Groups can represent data access DataSHIELD service access.
code: if (oadmin.user_exists(o, "userx"))   oadmin.user_delete(o, "userx") # generated password password <- oadmin.user_add(o, "userx", groups = c("demo", "datashield")) # verify user subset(oadmin.users(o), name == "userx")

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: set DataSHIELD-compatible permissions (view without accessing individual-level data) tables project, use following: Similarly, permissions use resources project DataSHIELD context even simpler: grant permission use DataSHIELD service group users: Note also possible grant permission access specific DataSHIELD profile (see Profiles section).
code: lapply(opal.tables(o, "CNSIM")$name, function(table) {   opal.table_perm_add(o, "CNSIM", table, subject = "demo", type = "group", permission = "view") }) # verify table permissions opal.table_perm(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM1") opal.resources_perm_add(o, "RSRC", subject = "demo", type = "group", permission = "view") # verify permissions opal.resources_perm(o, "RSRC") dsadmin.perm_add(o, subject = "datashield", type = "group", permission = "use") # verify permissions dsadmin.perm(o)

title: DataSHIELD Administration
text: Good practice free server resources sending logout request:
code: opal.logout(o)

title: Opal Projects
text: Setup connection Opal:
code: library(opalr) o <- opal.login("administrator", "password", url = "https://opal-demo.obiba.org")

title: Opal Projects
text: List projects: Create project, linked database (default first one):
code: opal.projects(o) if (opal.project_exists(o, "dummy"))   opal.project_delete(o, "dummy")   opal.project_create(o, "dummy", database = TRUE) opal.project(o, "dummy")

title: Opal Projects
text: Backup project download backup archive (encrypted): Restore project uploaded (encrypted) archive:
code: opal.project_backup(o, 'CNSIM', '/home/administrator/backup/CNSIM') opal.file_download(o, '/home/administrator/backup/CNSIM', '/tmp/CNSIM.zip', key = "12345abcdef") opal.file_upload(o, '/tmp/CNSIM.zip', '/home/administrator') opal.project_restore(o, 'dummy', '/home/administrator/CNSIM.zip', key = "12345abcdef") # verify tables opal.tables(o, "CNSIM")

title: Opal Projects
text: Opal two kinds tables: raw tables, data stored database, views, logical tables, using per-variable transformation algorithms. List tables project, count variables entities: table object can retrieved follow: existence table can checked: specifically, verify whether table view : table can created, either raw table view. create view, specify tables referred:
code: opal.tables(o, "CNSIM", counts = TRUE) opal.table(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM1", counts = TRUE) opal.table_exists(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM1") opal.table_exists(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM1", view = TRUE) # drop table if it exists opal.table_delete(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123") # then create a view, no variables opal.table_create(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123", tables = c("CNSIM.CNSIM1", "CNSIM.CNSIM2", "CNSIM.CNSIM3"))

title: Opal Projects
text: List variables table get details variable annotations (one column per variable attribute namespace). summary dictionary, includes concatenated category properties: also possible get full data dictionary table, separate data frames variables categories. recommended format working data dictionary: modify data dictionary appending derivation script variables: apply derived variables dictionary view previously created verify counts columns (variables) rows (entities) table: Assign view symbol R server, get summary statics:
code: opal.variables(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM1") dico <- opal.table_dictionary_get(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM1") dico$variables dico$categories dico$variables$script <- paste0("$('", dico$variables$name, "')") dico$variables opal.table_dictionary_update(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123", variables = dico$variables, categories = dico$categories) opal.table(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123", counts = TRUE) opal.assign(o, "D", "CNSIM.CNSIM123") opal.execute(o, "summary(D)")

title: Opal Projects
text: Get values table specific Participant entity: Get values table local R session data.frame (tibble) object: alterations data.frame save back raw table: Verify raw table resulting merge tables values given Participant: possible truncate table, .e. delete values table (must view), without modifying dictionary:
code: opal.valueset(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123", identifier = "1454") cnsim1 <- opal.table_get(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM1") cnsim2 <- opal.table_get(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM2") cnsim3 <- opal.table_get(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM3") # make sure IDs are unique cnsim1$id <- paste0(cnsim1$id, "-1") cnsim2$id <- paste0(cnsim2$id, "-2") cnsim3$id <- paste0(cnsim3$id, "-3") # bind tables cnsim123 <- rbind(cnsim1, cnsim2, cnsim3) # remove some columns cnsim123$DIS_AMI <- NULL cnsim123$DIS_CVA <- NULL cnsim123$DIS_DIAB <- NULL # save as a raw table opal.table_save(o, cnsim123, "CNSIM", "CNSIM", overwrite = TRUE, force = TRUE) opal.table(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM", counts = TRUE) opal.valueset(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM", identifier = "1454-1") opal.table_truncate(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM") opal.table(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM", counts = TRUE)

title: Opal Projects
text: Variables can described taxonomy terms. List taxonomies: List vocabularies taxonomy: List terms vocabulary: apply taxonomy term table dictionary, use following batch annotation: list variable annotations:
code: opal.taxonomies(o) opal.vocabularies(o, taxonomy = "Mlstr_area") opal.terms(o, taxonomy = "Mlstr_area", vocabulary = "Lifestyle_behaviours") annotations <- tibble::tribble(   ~variable, ~taxonomy, ~vocabulary, ~term,   "LAB_TSC", "Mlstr_area", "Physical_measures", "Physical_characteristics",   "LAB_TRIG", "Mlstr_area", "Physical_measures", "Physical_characteristics",   "LAB_HDL", "Mlstr_area", "Physical_measures", "Physical_characteristics",   "LAB_GLUC_ADJUSTED", "Mlstr_area", "Physical_measures", "Physical_characteristics" ) opal.annotate(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123", annotations = annotations) opal.annotations(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123")

title: Opal Projects
text: Resources alternative way accessing data computation systems. project stored references resources, .e. build resource object R permissions use resource. list resource references: create reference resource (compressed CSV file, stored Opal file system, authorized personal access token): resource reference, possible build get resource object local R session: Depending nature resource, may possible coerce data.frame client side: operation can done R server side:
code: opal.resources(o, "RSRC") if (opal.resource_exists(o, "RSRC", "CNSIM4"))   opal.resource_delete(o, "RSRC", "CNSIM4") opal.resource_create(o, "RSRC", "CNSIM4",     url = "opal+https://opal-demo.obiba.org/ws/files/projects/RSRC/CNSIM3.zip",     format = "csv", secret = "EeTtQGIob6haio5bx6FUfVvIGkeZJfGq") # verify the resource reference object opal.resource(o, "RSRC", "CNSIM4") opal.resource_get(o, "RSRC", "CNSIM4") library(resourcer) as.data.frame(opal.resource_get(o, "RSRC", "CNSIM4")) # assign the resource object opal.assign.resource(o, "rsrc", "RSRC.CNSIM4") # coerce it to a data.frame opal.assign.script(o, "D", quote(as.data.frame(rsrc))) # get some summary statistics opal.execute(o, "summary(as.factor(D$GENDER))")

title: Opal Projects
text: Permissions can managed (list, add, delete) different levels: project: opal.project_perm(), tables: opal.tables_perm(), table: opal.table_perm(), resources: opal.resources_perm(), resource: opal.resource_perm().

title: Opal Projects

code: opal.logout(o)

title: Opal R Session
text: Setup connection Opal, specifying R server session must created “default” profile, .e. “default” R servers cluster (note profile parameter optional):
code: library(opalr) o <- opal.login("administrator", "password", "https://opal-demo.obiba.org", profile = "default")

title: Opal R Session
text: Assign Opal table data.frame (user permission see values Opal table): place standard data.frame, Opal can assign data tibble: Resource objects can assigned R server session: R expression can also assigned symbol (use quote() interpret expression client side R session). example assign function body: List R symbols lives remote R session:
code: opal.assign.table(o, symbol = "df", value = "CNSIM.CNSIM1") opal.assign.table.tibble(o, symbol = "tbl", value = "CNSIM.CNSIM1") opal.assign.resource(o, symbol = "rsrc", value = "RSRC.CNSIM3") opal.assign.script(o, symbol = "hello", value = quote(function(x) { paste0("Hello ", x, "!") })) opal.symbols(o)

title: Opal R Session
text: R expressions can executed server side: remote data can downloaded client side R session: execute complex R code, use local source file:
code: # column names opal.execute(o, script = "names(tbl)") # get variable description from column attributes opal.execute(o, script = "attributes(tbl$GENDER)") # coerce resource to a data.frame and plot histogram of one column plot(opal.execute(o, script = "hist(as.data.frame(rsrc)$LAB_HDL)")) # execute the custom function opal.execute(o, script = "hello('friends')") GENDER <- opal.execute(o, script = "tbl$GENDER") opal.execute.source(o, path = "/path/to/some_code.R")

title: Opal R Session
text: Files can written Opal file system R server session folder: Similarly, files can read R server session folder Opal file system:
code: opal.file_write(o, source = "/projects/CNSIM/CNSIM3.zip", "test.zip") opal.file_read(o, source = "test.zip", destination = "/tmp")

title: Opal R Session
text: image remote R session can saved workspace (restored login time):
code: opal.workspace_save(o, save="demo") opal.workspaces(o)

code: opal.logout(o)

what: Opal Data Repository Client and DataSHIELD Utils
title: Opal Data Repository Client and DataSHIELD Utils
text: Opal R Client Opal data warehouse. web services Opal can reached opalr function: import/export, data dictionaries, projects, tables, resources, permissions, users, DataSHIELD profiles etc. See opalr documentation. Installation: Basic usage:
code: # install from CRAN install.packages("opalr")  # or install latest development version remotes::install_github("obiba/opalr") library(opalr) o <- opal.login('administrator', 'password', url = 'https://opal-demo.obiba.org')  # assign a table (as a data.frame) to a R symbol opal.assign(o, 'D', 'CNSIM.CNSIM1')  # perform R operations on the server side opal.execute(o, 'summary(D$GENDER)') opal.execute(o, 'summary(D$LAB_GLUC)')  opal.logout(o)

title: Opal Data Repository Client and DataSHIELD Utils
text: helper options can defined control default values behavior: opal.username, login user name (default NULL). opal.password, login user password (default NULL). opal.token, login personal access token (default NULL). opal.url, login Opal URL (default NULL). opal.opts, curl options (default NULL), see httr::httr_options. opal.profile, login profile (R servers cluster name) (default NULL). opal.progress, whether show progress bar (default TRUE). opal.progress.clear, whether clear progress bar completed (default FALSE). opal.retry.times, maximum number GET requests attempt (default 3, retry value 1). opal.retry.quiet, whether print message displaying long next request (default FALSE).

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # prepare datasets of visits, several visits for one patient visits <- tibble::tribble( ~id, ~patient_id, ~sex, ~visit_date, 1, 1, "M", as.Date("2020-01-01"), 2, 2, "F", as.Date("2020-01-02"), 3, 3, "M", as.Date("2020-01-03"), 4, 3, "M", as.Date("2020-01-04"))  o <- opal.login("administrator", "password", url = "https://opal-demo.obiba.org")  # save visits dataset opal.table_save(o, visits, "RSRC", "visits", type = "Visit", force = TRUE)  # get visit and make it a dataset of patients  patients <- opal.table_get(o, "RSRC", "visits", id.name = "id") # set dataset IDs patients$visit_id <- patients$id patients$id <- patients$patient_id patients$patient_id <- NULL patients  # save patients dataset, there should be a warning that some variables are not repeatable # while there are patients with multiple data lines opal.table_save(o, patients, "RSRC", "patients", type = "Participant", force = TRUE)  opal.logout(o) } # }

title: Get DataSHIELD logs — dsadmin.log
text: DataSHIELD log structured follows:

code: dsadmin.log(opal, all = TRUE)

title: Get DataSHIELD logs — dsadmin.log
text: opal Opal connection object. Get latest log messages.

title: Get DataSHIELD logs — dsadmin.log
text: Common fields timestamp: action logged version: used message: human readable message logger_name: name log channel thread_name: java thread name level: log level (TRACE, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR) level_value: log level numeric value ip: ip origin request, available ds_id: unique DS session ID ds_profile: DS profile name (available R server session created, can authentication) username: DS user name r_duration: time spent remote R server action (except PARSE) r_size: R result serialized object size bytes ds_action: DS operation (OPEN, CLOSE, PARSE, ASSIGN, AGGREGATE, LS, RM, WS_SAVE, WS_RESTORE) DS operations fields OPEN: DS session opened (note: happens successful authentication R server session creation deferred) CLOSE: DS session closed PARSE: R expression parsed ds_map: DS function mappings used R parser, separated semicolons several functions called ds_script_in: R script sent DS user ds_script_out: R script rewritten opal, evaluated ASSIGN: ds_symbol: assigned symbol name ds_table: table name assigned ds_resource: resource name assigned ds_eval: assign R expression evaluated AGGREGATE: ds_eval: aggregate R expression evaluated LS: R symbols listed RM: R symbol removed ds_symbol: symbol name remove WS_SAVE: ds_ws: workspace name WS_RESTORE: ds_ws: workspace name

title: Data or expression assignment — opal.assign
text: opal Opal object list opal objects. symbol Name R symbol. value value assign evaluated following order: R expression, function, fully qualified name variable table Opal R object (data.frame, vector). variables List variable names Javascript expression selects variables table (ignored value refere table). See javascript documentation: http://wiki.obiba.org/display/OPALDOC/Variable+Methods missings TRUE, missing values pushed Opal R, default FALSE. Ignored value R expression. identifiers Name identifiers mapping use assigning entities R (Opal 2.0). id.name Add vector given name representing entity identifiers (Opal 2.6). Default NULL. updated.name Add vector given name representing creation last update timestamps (Opal 2.6). Default NULL. async R script executed asynchronously within session (default FALSE). TRUE, value returned ID command look (Opal 2.1).

title: Data or expression assignment — opal.assign
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ o <- opal.login('administrator','password', url='https://opal-demo.obiba.org') # assign a list of variables from table CNSIM1 opal.assign(o, symbol="D", value="datashield.CNSIM1", variables=list("GENDER","LAB_TSC")) # assign all the variables matching 'LAB' from table HOP of opal object o opal.assign(o, symbol="D", value="datashield.CNSIM1", variables="name().matches('LAB_')") # assign a function and call it opal.assign.script(o, 'hello', quote(function(x) { print(paste0('Hello ', x , '!'))})) opal.execute(o, "hello('Mr Bean')") # push an arbitrary data frame to the R server #opal.assign(o, "D", mtcars) # push an arbitrary vector to the R server #opal.assign(o, "C", mtcars$cyl) opal.logout(o) } # }

title: Opal login — opal.login
text: Log Opal(s). Different login strategies possible: (1) providing username/password, (2) providing username/password one-time password code (TOPT) user activated two-factor authentication, (3) providing personal access token (PAT), (4) providing key pair PEM format.

title: Opal login — opal.login
code: opal.login(   username = getOption("opal.username"),   password = getOption("opal.password"),   token = getOption("opal.token"),   url = getOption("opal.url"),   opts = getOption("opal.opts", list()),   profile = getOption("opal.profile"),   restore = NULL,   context = "r" )

title: Opal login — opal.login
text: username User name opal(s). Can provided "opal.username" option. password User password opal(s). Can provided "opal.password" option. token Personal access token (since opal 2.15). effective username password NULL empty. Can provided "opal.token" option. url Opal url list opal urls. Can provided "opal.url" option. Secure http (https) connection required. opts Curl options described httr (call httr::httr_options() details). Can provided "opal.opts" option. profile R server profile name. drive R server R session created. remote R session needed (Opal specific operations done), parameter need provided. Otherwise, missing, default R server profile applied ('default'). See also opal.profiles. Can provided "opal.profile" option. restore Workspace ID restored (see also opal.logout) context Context R session created. Either "r" (default) "datashield".

title: Opal login — opal.login
text: opal object list opal objects.

title: Opal login — opal.login
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ #### The below examples illustrate the different ways to login in opal ####  # explicite username/password login o <- opal.login(username = 'administrator', password = 'password',                  url = 'https://opal-demo.obiba.org') opal.logout(o)   # explicite personal access token login o <- opal.login(token = 'HYG16LO0VaX4O0UardNbiqmr2ByBpRke',                  url = 'https://opal-demo.obiba.org') opal.logout(o)  # login using options and user credentials options(opal.username = 'administrator',  opal.password = 'password',  opal.url = 'https://opal-demo.obiba.org') o <- opal.login() opal.logout(o)  # login using options and personal access token options(opal.token = 'HYG16LO0VaX4O0UardNbiqmr2ByBpRke',         opal.url = 'https://opal-demo.obiba.org') o <- opal.login() opal.logout(o)  # login using ssl key pair options(opal.opts = list(           sslcert = 'my-publickey.pem',           sslkey = 'my-privatekey.pem')) o <- opal.login(url = 'https://opal-demo.obiba.org') opal.logout(o)  # login with a R server profile o <- opal.login(username = 'administrator', password = 'password',                  url = 'https://opal-demo.obiba.org', profile = 'default') opal.logout(o) } # }

title: Update the dictionary of a Opal table — opal.table_dictionary_update
text: opal Opal connection object. project Project name table located. table Destination table name. variables data frame one row per variable (column name) one column per property/attribute (Opal Excel format). categories data frame one row per category (columns variable name) column per property/attribute (Opal Excel format). categories, parameter optional. complete logical indicate provided dictionary complete, .e. variables included dictionary must removed view. code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ o <- opal.login('administrator','password', url='https://opal-demo.obiba.org') # make a view opal.table_view_create(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123",                        c("CNSIM.CNSIM1"))  # update the table references opal.table_view_update(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123",                        tables = c("CNSIM.CNSIM1", "CNSIM.CNSIM2", "CNSIM.CNSIM3"))  # update the entity filter opal.table_view_update(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123", where = "$('LAB_TSC').ge(5)")  # remove the entity filter opal.table_view_update(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123", where = "")  # update both the table references and the entity filter opal.table_view_update(o, "CNSIM", "CNSIM123",                        tables = c("CNSIM.CNSIM1", "CNSIM.CNSIM2", "CNSIM.CNSIM3"),                        where = "$('LAB_TSC').ge(5)") opal.logout(o) } # }

title: Create a personal access token for R usage — opal.token_r_create

what: opalr: 'Opal' Data Repository Client and 'DataSHIELD' Utils — opalr-package
title: opalr: 'Opal' Data Repository Client and 'DataSHIELD' Utils — opalr-package
text: Data integration Web application biobanks 'OBiBa'. 'Opal' core database application biobanks. Participant data, collected data source, must integrated stored central data repository uniform model. 'Opal' central repository. can import, process, validate, query, analyze, report, export data. 'Opal' typically used research center analyze data acquired assessment centres. ultimate purpose achieve seamless data-sharing among biobanks. 'Opal' client allows interact 'Opal' web services perform operations R server side. 'DataSHIELD' administration tools also provided.
